content: The Senate's procedures are based on various sources including standing orders, precedents, statutes, and informal practices. Reference sources provide information on how these authorities govern parliamentary situations, establishing the framework for Senate business. This report discusses the availability of reference sources like the Senate Manual and Riddick's Senate Procedure, covering rules, precedents, and publications from Senate committees and party conferences. It also reviews principles of Senate parliamentary procedure. This report reviews Senate parliamentary procedure principles and official reference sources, including the Senate Manual and Riddick's Senate Procedure. It also covers party conference rules and additional publications providing background information on parliamentary authorities. Text boxes offer guidance on accessing these sources online for Senators and congressional staff. This report provides information on Senate parliamentary procedure principles and official reference sources, including the Senate Manual and Riddick's Senate Procedure. It includes appendixes with a selected list of CRS products on Senate procedure and an overview of primary websites for accessing resources. Senate procedures are based on various sources, and Senators can seek guidance from the Office of the Senate Parliamentarian or CRS staff. The Senate has the authority to make its own rules, often enforced by unanimous consent. The Senate has the constitutional power to make its own rules of procedure, often enforced by unanimous consent. Senate procedures are based on various sources, including standing rules, precedents, statutory provisions, and informal practices. Senators must often initiate enforcement of their rules, follow precedents, and adhere to informal practices. The Senate has the authority to determine its rules of procedure, which are based on standing rules, precedents, statutory provisions, and informal practices. Priority of recognition is given to certain leaders, allowing them to influence Senate proceedings. The Senate can amend standing rules or create new ones by majority vote, demonstrating its rulemaking power. The Senate has the authority to determine its rules of procedure through standing rules, precedents, and statutes. It can create new rules by majority vote or waive existing rules by unanimous consent or a two-thirds vote. The Senate lacks the ability to supersede its rules by majority vote like the House can with a "special rule." The Senate's presiding officer can overrule decisions or sustain points of order by majority vote, setting precedents for future rulings. Violations of Senate rules can occur unless a Senator raises a point of order. The presiding officer can submit questions of order to the Senate for decision under Rule XX. The Senate can appeal the ruling of the presiding officer on a point of order by majority vote, establishing a precedent for future decisions. Informal practices and party conference rules do not have the authority of Senate rules and procedures. The Senate often operates outside its standing rules through unanimous consent agreements, which allow for the consideration of measures, amendments, and floor procedures. These agreements are carefully crafted by the majority leader in consultation with other Senators to ensure smooth legislative processes. The Senate operates outside its standing rules through unanimous consent agreements, crafted by the majority leader in consultation with other Senators. These agreements have the same authority as Senate rules, can only be altered by unanimous consent, and are enforced on the Senate floor. Senate precedents detail how rules are interpreted and applied, complementing and supplementing the standing rules. Precedents, akin to case law, are crucial in understanding Senate proceedings. Precedents in the Senate, similar to case law, play a crucial role in determining proceedings. Senators cite precedents to support arguments, defend against points of order, or appeal rulings by the presiding officer. These precedents influence how current Senate rules are applied by relating past decisions to the specific case at hand. Most precedents are established through Senate votes on questions of order or when the presiding officer's ruling is not appealed. The Senate typically follows these precedents unless a decision is reversed or modified. Precedents in the Senate are crucial for determining proceedings. The Senate follows precedents unless reversed or modified. Precedents based on Senate votes carry more weight than those from the presiding officer. Recent precedents hold more weight than older ones, and those reflecting established patterns are more authoritative. Precedents must be evaluated in historical context. Senators can consult the Senate Parliamentarian's Office for precedents. The Senate's rules and practices are established over time, and Senators can consult the Senate Parliamentarian's Office for precedents. Unofficial practices have evolved and become accepted customs, although they do not have the same standing as official rules. The Senate Manual compiles official parliamentary authorities periodically in a new edition. The Senate Manual compiles official parliamentary authorities periodically in a new edition, including Standing Rules of the Senate, Rules for Regulation of the Senate Wing, and Constitution of the United States of America. Each authority is detailed with section numbers running throughout the Manual. The Senate Manual compiles official parliamentary authorities periodically in a new edition, including Standing Rules of the Senate. Each authority is detailed with section numbers that run throughout the Manual in a single sequence and always appear in bold type. The Senate does not re-adopt its standing rules at the beginning of each new Congress but instead regards its rules as continuing in effect without need for re-adoption. Changes to the standing rules are proposed in the form of Senate resolutions, which can be adopted by majority vote. At the start of the 116th Congress, there were 44 standing rules of the Senate. Changes to the standing rules of the Senate are proposed through Senate resolutions and can be adopted by majority vote. The standing rules are set forth in the Manual with footnotes indicating amendments since 1979. Standing orders, although not part of the standing rules, have the same authority and are enforceable on the Senate floor. These orders remain in effect until repealed by the Senate and are compiled in sections 60-139 of the Manual. The Manual compiles permanent standing orders of the Senate, including statutes related to Senate administration and operations. It provides headings, citations to Senate resolutions, and footnotes for supplementary information. The Manual compiles permanent standing orders of the Senate, including statutes related to Senate administration and operations. It covers Senate procedures, rulemaking statutes, and constitutional requirements such as maintaining an official Journal, quorum for business, yea and nay votes, and exclusive powers like advice and consent on treaties and impeachments. The text of the Constitution and its amendments are also included in the Manual. The Senate Manual includes the text of the Constitution and its amendments, with bold brackets around amended text. Senate Rule XXXIII authorizes the Senate Committee on Rules and Administration to make rules for the Capitol complex. Regulations address floor activities like secretaries' duties, legislative buzzers, and display materials in the Senate chamber. The Senate has adopted rules for its proceedings as a Court of Impeachment. Cleaves' Manual provides rules and precedents for Senate practice regarding conference committees. Many principles from Cleaves' Manual still apply to current practice. Cleaves' Manual includes excerpts from the Manual of Parliamentary Practice by Thomas Jefferson and other Vice Presidents and Speakers, Senate rules, principles established by precedent, and forms for conference reports. Riddick's Senate Procedure is a comprehensive reference source covering Senate rules and precedents, with the current edition published in 1992 covering precedents from 1883 to 1992. Riddick's Senate Procedure: Precedents and Practices, published in 1992, covers Senate precedents from 1883 to 1992. It presents Senate precedents and customary practices organized by procedural topics in alphabetical order, with summaries of general principles and relevant rules or provisions. The volume also includes subject headings and subtopics for individual precedents, such as "Cloture Procedure" with topics like "Amendments After Cloture." Riddick's Senate Procedure covers Senate precedents from 1883 to 1992, organized by procedural topics in alphabetical order. The publication includes subject headings like "Amendments After Cloture," with 18 topics such as "Drafted Improperly" and "Filing of Amendments." Footnotes provide citations to establish precedents and sample floor dialogues showing Senate terminology. The main index helps locate information on specific Senate procedure topics. The Senate establishes standing orders through unanimous consent agreements, effective for a limited period, usually for a Congress. These orders are adopted at the start of each new Congress and are not included in the Senate Manual but appear in the Congressional Record. For example, during the 116th Congress, the Senate adopted 11 unanimous consent agreements re-establishing standing orders on various procedural topics. These agreements also serve as parliamentary authorities in the Senate. The Senate establishes standing orders through unanimous consent agreements, which serve as parliamentary authorities in the Senate. These agreements override standing rules and other procedural authorities, setting conditions for floor consideration of specified measures. UC agreements are propounded orally, printed in the Congressional Record, and enforced like standing rules. Accepted agreements are printed in the Senate's daily Calendar of Business until they expire. The Senate's standing rules require committees to adopt written rules of procedure by March 1 of each Congress. Committee rules cover important aspects like preparing reports and issuing subpoenas, and subcommittees may have their own rules. These rules do not supersede Senate standing rules. Committee rules are published in the Congressional Record and sometimes in committee prints or online. The Senate Committee on Rules and Administration compiles all committee rules in a document each Congress. The Senate's standing rules require committees to adopt written rules of procedure by March 1 of each Congress. These rules cover important aspects like preparing reports and issuing subpoenas. The document, Authority and Rules of Senate Committees, presents the jurisdiction statement for each committee and related information on committee procedures. The Senate establishes procedural regulations through simple resolutions or statutory measures, which have the same standing as Senate and House rules. The Senate's rulemaking provisions assert authority through sections like "Exercise of Rulemaking Power," which can be changed through simple resolutions. These provisions stem from Legislative Reorganization Acts, expedited procedures, and budget-related statutes. Congressional budget resolutions also play a role in regulating actions in the budget process. Key rulemaking statutes include the Legislative Reorganization Acts of 1946 and 1970. The Legislative Reorganization Acts of 1946 and 1970 are important rulemaking statutes that influenced legislative procedures. These statutes included provisions that were later incorporated into the Senate's standing rules and the Senate Manual. Rulemaking statutes define special procedures for congressional approval or disapproval of actions proposed by the executive branch or independent agencies, such as the Congressional Review Act. The Congressional Review Act outlines special procedures for Congress to overturn federal agency rules. Key rulemaking statutes like the Congressional Budget Act establish procedures for budgetary legislation consideration. The concurrent resolution on the budget sets a budget plan for the fiscal year and includes procedural regulations for subsequent budget-related measures. The Congressional Budget Act establishes procedural regulations for budget-related measures, including new points of order and "pay-as-you-go" procedures. These provisions can be temporary or permanent and are found in congressional budget resolutions. Conference rules from party conferences in the Senate are not enforceable on the Senate floor. The Senate Republican Conference adopted rules for the 116th Congress that cover topics such as the selection of party leaders, meetings, and committee assignments.
